I suspect the staying power of the media is, like that of Republicans, is far greater than any sane nation would allow. >>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<< At least at my Occupy, we have been building alliances - with unions, with Veterans for Peace, with existing local social justice groups.  We're running joint marches and rallies with other groups.  We're building alliances with each other, for that matter - it's not like everybody at the camp is from the same school of thought, we just happen to be in basic agreement that certain things are wrong, and now at this camp people are talking to each other who weren't before.  I see alliance-building as one of the most interesting things happening.  So I'm not sure where Kevin is getting the idea that it's not happening (possibly other Occupys are doing, or not doing, different stuff). I highly encourage you to check out your local Occupy, if only to see firsthand what it's doing, and possibly to help. >>> END COMMENT <<< ### Targets ### •America / USA •Journalists •Black people •Elites •Vegetarians / Vegans •Taxes are (good | fair) •Hobbies •Democrats •The government •Military •Kamala Harris •Police •Food •Capitalism •Christians •Covid •Hillary Clinton •Nancy Pelosi •Diversity •Socialism / Communism •Israel •Muslims •Woke •White people •Fascism / Nazism •Jobs are (available | good) •Fossil fuels •Climate change is (real | a problem) •Social media •Feminism •Republicans (GOP) •Barack Obama •Movies •Christianity •Conservatives •Ukraine •Vaccines •Gay / LGTBQ+ •Drugs •Media •Progressives •Liberals •Sport •Music •Economy is good •Russia •Scientists •Joe Biden •Politicians •Sarah Palin •Islam •Crime •Abortion •Healthcare •Jews •Donald Trump •China •Terrorism •Social welfare •Immigration / immigrants ### Task Description ### For each target, determine the stance in the comment: - If the stance is in favor of the target or agrees with the target, write FAVOR - If the stance is against the target or disagrees with the target, write AGAINST - If the stance is ambiguous, write NONE - If the comment is not related to the target, write NOT RELATED ### KEY CLAIM ### - Extract the fundamental assertion or belief that form the basis of the commenter's stance - The key claim should be expressed impersonalizing the user in the form of "I agree with the following: ". - If no stance is expressed (NOT RELATED, NONE) then leave the explanation field empty. ### Output Format: ### You must output only JSON format: { "results": [ { "target": "", "stance": "", "stance_type": "", "explanation": " if stance in FAVOR/AGAINST" }, // Repeat for each target ] } ONLY return the JSON object itself.

# News comment title:
The Future of #OWS

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
I'd like to see them vary their tactics a bit. Instead of large-scale occupations, how about Vietnam War era-style marches. HUGE marches. The media would have to cover that. Sooner or later the occupations are going to try the patience of the good bourgeois taxpayers who merely want to use their parks, or get home without snarled traffic. 

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
In 1998 the Republican Party impeached a sitting President over consensual sex, the leader of the charge was discovered to have been doing exactly what he was accusing the President of doing, and the next guy they found resigned within days over his own sex life.  There was no way the Republican Party could rebound from that - two years later (in spite of losing the election) we had a Republican President.

After eight years of incompetence, malice, a wildly successful terrorist attack, an incompetently run war of vengeance, a stunningly incompetently run war of aggression, and a devastated economy, the idiot Republicans were driven from power for good.

Two years later they controlled the House and enough of the Senate to block any and all action to improve the lives of Americans.

I suspect the staying power of the media is, like that of Republicans, is far greater than any sane nation would allow.

>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<


There are actually marches and rallies in Boston (where you, like myself, apparently live), mostly launching from the camp itself, a few times a week.  Some of them are joint productions (for instance, today there's a march/rally with the Massachusetts Nurses' Association).  Unfortunately, most of them are pretty small (200 people max).  Clearly you should come to a march that suits your fancy, and get other people to do so as well. :)

This week alone I think there have been five marches already, not including the one today (Friday 10/28) and the one tomorrow.

You can find the daily schedule, which includes most marches and rallies (though for some reason not all), at http://www.occupyboston.org/calendar/

(A minor nitpick: Aren't marches what snarls the traffic and annoys car commuters in the first place?  Certainly, people are not blocking traffic when they're in the park in Dewey Square.)

>>> END COMMENT <<<

### Overview ### Stance classification is the task of determining the expressed or implied opinion, or stance, of a statement toward a certain, specified target. Your task is to analyze the news comment and determine its stances towards specific targets. ### Context ### Comment posted on date: 2014-05-19 23:08:29 # News comment title: What's the End Game for the Trigger Warning Movement? # Most liked comment (from the thread): The students should be required to put trigger warnings on their term papers warning the professors of the mind-numbing inanity they will be subjected to. >>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<< Maybe I can shed some light on this, Kevin, as someone who both has PTSD and works a lot with people with PTSD (I volunteer as a rape crisis counselor). Triggers aren't about being "upset". They aren't about people being "sensitive". I have PTSD because I did, and still do, work that exposed me to the risk and sights of severe violence and that most of the people complaining about trigger warnings would not be willing to do themselves (i.e. being a medic at protests). And like I said, I volunteer as a rape crisis counselor. The problem is not that I am "sensitive", the problem is that certain stimuli, especially if I'm not expecting them, can cause me to re-experience traumatic experiences - intense physical symptoms of fear or horror and rushing adrenaline, even full-blown panic attacks. It's a medical episode. It can throw off my emotional balance for hours, or days if it's bad enough, leaving me irritable and upset. It has nothing to do with wanting to be shielded from the bad things in the world - I still do the work that I was doing when I got traumatized in the first place, but when I go into it I know what might be coming and that makes such a huge difference. I have a chance to prepare myself. I have a chance to check myself, make sure this is something I can really deal with at that time. With all the articles about trigger warnings lately, I'm getting really tired of hearing how weak and delicate I supposedly am to have triggers (or how I must be some ultra-privileged person who has triggers because I've been so oversheltered and didn't see enough pictures of the Holocaust or whatever growing up). Triggers are idiosyncratic, which I think is something that some people in the trigger warning movement, as you call it, miss. For example, I have a friend who is triggered by all the movies of a particular famous director, because one of his movies was playing in the background when she was assaulted. The Geek Feminism Wiki has a link to the account of someone who is triggered by calculus because she was studying calculus during the months that she was being repeatedly sexually abused. I've talked to people who are triggered by taking showers because they were raped in the rain. For a while I had a popular song as a mild trigger. So yeah, you're never going to be able to account for all people's triggers. People have weird triggers. Anyone who has triggers, unless they are very new to the experience, is going to have done a fair amount of work learning what they are and how to manage them. However, actual depictions of the thing that traumatized them in the first place are very common triggers. So you can address a lot of triggers by warning people about the obvious things! Is it really so arduous for a prof to briefly mention "Just so you know, this film that we're watching has a rape scene in it"? Binky, below, gives a fine example of how this can work with racist language, that would cover both people who would actually be triggered by it and people who would be sort of upset, while doing zero harm and posing zero threat to academic freedom. It's just a courtesy. Are there people who are co-opting the notion of triggers, using them to mean "Anything that upsets me"? Yep, and those people are annoying. But you get that with everything - people saying that they have OCD because they are neat, that they are autistic because they are mildly socially awkward, that they have the flu because they have a cold. Does real life have trigger warnings? Well, sometimes it does, sometimes it doesn't. Usually not worded as such, of course, but I don't routinely click on links to stories about police brutality that don't have "police brutality" or a similar indicative phrase somewhere in the title or URL. Stories about rape usually have headlines or blurbs that make it clear what they're about. Movies have a blurb on the back of the box that can give you some idea of what you're getting into, or you can read reviews. Friends who have some idea of your past experiences will say "Hey, there's a scene in this movie that you might have trouble with." It's just a way to make things a little easier for people who have lasting psychological effects from trauma (or people with other psychological issues where episodes can be triggered, like other anxiety disorders or eating disorders). >>> END COMMENT <<< ### Targets ### •America / USA •Journalists •Black people •Elites •Vegetarians / Vegans •Taxes are (good | fair) •Hobbies •Democrats •The government •Military •Kamala Harris •Police •Food •Capitalism •Christians •Covid •Hillary Clinton •Nancy Pelosi •Diversity •Socialism / Communism •Israel •Muslims •Woke •White people •Fascism / Nazism •Jobs are (available | good) •Fossil fuels •Climate change is (real | a problem) •Social media •Feminism •Republicans (GOP) •Barack Obama •Movies •Christianity •Conservatives •Ukraine •Vaccines •Gay / LGTBQ+ •Drugs •Media •Progressives •Liberals •Sport •Music •Economy is good •Russia •Scientists •Joe Biden •Politicians •Sarah Palin •Islam •Crime •Abortion •Healthcare •Jews •Donald Trump •China •Terrorism •Social welfare •Immigration / immigrants ### Task Description ### For each target, determine the stance in the comment: - If the stance is in favor of the target or agrees with the target, write FAVOR - If the stance is against the target or disagrees with the target, write AGAINST - If the stance is ambiguous, write NONE - If the comment is not related to the target, write NOT RELATED ### KEY CLAIM ### - Extract the fundamental assertion or belief that form the basis of the commenter's stance - The key claim should be expressed impersonalizing the user in the form of "I agree with the following: ". - If no stance is expressed (NOT RELATED, NONE) then leave the explanation field empty. ### Output Format: ### You must output only JSON format: { "results": [ { "target": "", "stance": "", "stance_type": "", "explanation": " if stance in FAVOR/AGAINST" }, // Repeat for each target ] } ONLY return the JSON object itself.

# News comment title:
What's the End Game for the Trigger Warning Movement?

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
The students should be required to put trigger warnings on their term papers warning the professors of the mind-numbing inanity they will be subjected to.

>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<


A warning that this program "contains violence" is a crappy trigger warning.  If I'm warning about a story I'm linking to, I would say something like "contains a detailed description of sexual assault" or "contains a picture of the victim of a racially-motivated attack" or whatever.

You're correct, in your earlier post, that triggers are idiosyncratic, but a lot of people - including some with really weird triggers - are still triggered by depictions of trauma that remind them of the trauma they experienced.  So a warning about, say, rape, isn't going to cover everyone who's been traumatized by rape, but it'll cover quite a few.  You can't prevent all cases of people being triggered, but you can reduce them.  I talk about this some in my longer comment.  I have, and have had, both "obvious" triggers and "random" triggers.

>>> END COMMENT <<<

This is exactly the kind of comment that makes these arguments suck for me as someone with PTSD. You're saying that having triggers means that I can't take care of myself and that I'm not tough. Would you say that of someone with any other kind of disability asking for a mild accommodation at work or school? I can survive on my own in the wilderness for three days, I volunteer as a rape crisis counselor, I did disaster relief in the projects after Hurricane Sandy, I face off with riot police lines and risk injury to protect people. But I have these triggers because I watched police nearly kill people in front of me and swing batons at my head and I patched up people who didn't have access to real medical treatment while not being sure that they'd all survive the day. I really don't think this makes me a bad feminist. This is also not about chivalric ideals or gender inequality. # News comment title:
President Obama Not Thrilled With Trigger Warnings

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
He's talking about censorship, not trigger warnings. Trigger warnings are not there to say "No one should read this book" they are to help people who have experienced trauma to either be prepared for or avoid reading/watching/listening to something that will trigger memories of their trauma.

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
He's talking about censorship, not trigger warnings. Trigger warnings are not there to say "No one should read this book" they are to help people who have experienced trauma to either be prepared for or avoid reading/watching/listening to something that will trigger memories of their trauma.

>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<


Nothing he said is about trigger warnings.  Trigger warnings aren't about censorship or being protected from different points of view, they're about providing a heads up that around certain topics.  They have been around (and debated) in the feminist blogosphere, and in a lot of fandom writing, for years - they weren't invented by Kids These Days, they're an import to academia from the Internet.


I'm getting awfully tired of "Can you tell me if you're going to show police brutality so that I don't have a flashback?" (or someone else's version of something similar, whether it involves flashbacks or being put into some other bad mental state that's not helpful for engaging with the material) being interpreted, even by stodgier liberals, as "I want to censor this, nobody should write or talk about it!"  And even more tired of the "coddling" narrative - people typically get triggers either through trauma or through struggling with some major mental illness like an eating disorder or depression, and neither trauma nor illness suggests too much coddling in life.


Microaggressions are also not particularly related to trigger warnings, even if the same people often talk about both.  Microaggressions are just the little instances of getting shit for your race, gender, class, sexual orientation, etc, that happen often and thus add up to something more.  The Kids These Days didn't invent the word "microaggression" either (if anything, I'd guess someone in academia invented it, making it a bit rich for academics to act like it's a concept that's bad for academia).  I first heard the word years ago in a blog post from Female Science Professor, a physical science full professor, old enough to have an adolescent child, at a research university, who used to blog about science and sexism in science.  I doubt she invented it either.

>>> END COMMENT <<<

I don't know that "thicker skin" is necessary or desirable, but I have some thoughts on grounding techniques that can help with anxiety/stress spikes.  These are largely things I've learned from volunteering as a rape crisis counselor and in other "emotional first aid" type roles, and some of them are things I've used in my own life.  Not all will be helpful for all people.  None of them are meant to suggest that the source of the problem is the person feeling the anxiety and stress; they are just meant to reduce the feeling, because the feeling can be very unpleasant.

- Take five deep breaths, concentrating on keeping them even and not too fast (most resting adults take one breath every 3-5 seconds).  Find five emotionally neutral or positive things you see.  Take five more breaths.  Find five emotionally neutral or positive things you hear.  Take five more breaths.  Do the same exercise with touch, and actually touch the things if you can.  Take five more breaths.  In general, being mindful of breathing is really useful, because anxiety and hyperventilation reinforce each other (anxiety causes hyperventilation, hyperventilation causes shallow breathing which causes oxygen deprivation which causes anxiety, now you have a cycle).

- If there's a smell or taste that you associate with safety, seek it out.  If it's something portable and you need to do this frequently, you can even carry it with you.

- Pick a color and find everything in the room that has that color in it.

- Play with something you can squeeze and twist - play-doh or silly putty, a stress ball, something like that.  Or something you can stretch and twist, like those rubber bracelets that every organization seems to give out these days.  The rubber bracelets are nice because they're small.  When I was on trial recently I took one to court with me every day, and when I was on the stand I was playing with one the whole time, both to reduce stress and to have something to do with my hands so that I wasn't fidgeting the whole time.

- A lot of people like coloring.  They find the simple, repetitive motion calming.  Something like knitting might also work for this if you're experienced enough to find the motion simple.

- Cardiovascular exercise is helpful for a lot of people.  Alternatively, just going for a walk can be helpful.

- Processing with a sympathetic friend.

- To break from a panic attack or something like that, some people find cold helpful - putting a cold pack against your skin, throwing cold water on your face, taking a cool shower, that kind of thing.

- You're a tech guy.  There are a bunch of relaxation and de-stresssing apps, as well as mood-tracker apps that are meant to help people figure out what works for them, PTSD symptom management apps, all kinds of things.

You might also try googling progressive muscle relaxation, or having a therapist do it with you.  In general, therapists can be very useful for stuff like this, but I haven't emphasized that because several other people in this thread have done so already.

Kevin, I think you have the causation backwards on Bernie. People who already believed that, of which millennials are probably a disproportionate fraction, were attracted to Bernie's candidacy, because it was the candidacy of a relative outsider who made a few noises about things that were already bothering them. As it happens, despite not liking Hillary, I campaigned pretty heavily for her in New Hampshire, because my approach to national electoral politics is pretty hardline pragmatic.
